summary.text_en: Maxwell unified electricity and magnetism with 4 elegant equations, predicting electromagnetic waves. He discovered light is an electromagnetic wave!

story.text_en: While studying Faraday's electromagnetic induction, Maxwell described electricity-magnetism relationship with equations. He found: changing electric fields produce magnetic fields, changing magnetic fields produce electric fields. Combined, they create self-propagating wavesâ€”electromagnetic waves! He calculated their speed, astonished to find it exactly equals light speed.

fun_facts.text_en: Maxwell took the world's first color photograph! Using red, green, blue filters separately then combining.
He also studied color theory, finding any color can be mixed from RGB primaries.
He had a cat and installed the world's first 'cat door'!

experiment.description_en: Move magnet quickly through coil, connected bulb lights up! This proves changing magnetic field produces electric current. Generators work on this principle.
experiment.why_en: Moving magnet changes magnetic field, producing electric field per Faraday's law, driving current.

simple_explanation.text_en: Maxwell discovered electricity and magnetism are related! They produce waves (electromagnetic waves) propagating through space. Light, radio waves, WiFi are all electromagnetic waves, just different 'colors' (frequencies)!

impact.text_en: Maxwell's equations are one of physics' greatest achievements, providing theoretical foundation for all wireless technologies: radio, TV, phones, radar. Einstein called it 'the most profound change in physics since Newton'.

influenced.contribution_en: Studying electromagnetic radiation led to quantum theory
Electromagnetic theory is basis of quantum electrodynamics

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Maxwell built on Faraday's experimental discoveries, using Newton's mathematical methods to establish equations. He predicted constant light speed, puzzling physicists for 40 years until Einstein's relativity resolved it. Maxwell's equations also underpin quantum electrodynamics, influencing all 20th-century physics.
